In vain, foolish heart, do you grieve</br>And fruitless those tears that do flow,</br>Yet weeping does sorrow relieve;</br>And a sigh is a comfort for woe.
Ah me!  my Fidelia, no more</br>With thee thro' the valley I'll stray</br>The valley that pleas'd me before,</br>Alas!  it no longer seems gay.
How heavenly then was her speech!</br>How fondly upon it I hung!</br>She spoke what an angel might teach:</br>And wisdom dropp'd sweet from her tongue.
Yet ne'er cou'd my simpleton heart,</br>Tho' goodness beam'd rich from her eye,</br>The flow of its feeling impart,</br>No language it knew but — a sigh.
Did I but attempt to disclose</br>The passion that reign'd in my breast,</br>In love-taught confusion it rose,</br>And the new-born accents represt.
Yet sure she ne'er pointed a frown;</br>Ne'er drest her in dignity look;</br>No guardian contempt sent down,</br>To discourage the freedom I took.
Oh no!  she is meek as the morn,</br>In May that illumines the green;</br>As the air from the sweet-scented thorn;</br>As the breath of honey-mouth'd bean.
She is mild as the Moon's milky beam,</br>That silent steals over the hills;</br>She is gentle as heavens sent dream,</br>That the mind of an innocent fills.
When we parted she tenderly sigh'd;</br>Soft pity her bosom did swell</br>When I wept with compassion she cry'd,</br>She scarcely cou'd sob out — farewell.
"How vain are all forms and and art!</br>How mean!" my Fidelia wou'd say;</br>"They fetter the spring of the heart,</br>And dim the affectionate ray.
"Sure nought can forbid, that is good,</br>The pleasing converse of a friend;</br>True modesty ne'er was a prude;</br>On shew it can never depend."
Then can my Fidelia grieve?</br>Can friendship her bosom so move?</br>Must he whom she weeps so to leave,</br>Despair of obtaining her love?
Hush'd-dead be such thought in my breast—</br>O no!  She must never be mine—</br>Tho' to think it be death to my rest,</br>Compell'd by my fate I resign.
Some youth she's allotted to bless</br>Who shines in a loftier sphere—</br>He may triumph — my fortune is less—</br>But I'll die if he hold her so dear.
No cattle have I that might low</br>The music of wealth in her ear;</br>Not a sheep, not a lamb, can shew,</br>To prove my affection sincere.
Ah!  thus may the fortunate woo,</br>Who have drank of felicity's show'r—</br>I have nought but a heart that is true—</br>Alack!  What a pitiful dow'r.
Yet shed, ye kind Gods, on the pair</br>The joy that I never can have—</br>Long after I'm eas'd of my care—</br>Long after I'm laid in — my grave.
A stranger henceforth to delight,</br>To solitude's comfort I'll fly—</br>I will court the sweet gloom of the night,</br>And chaunt to the nightingale's sigh.
When midnight's black horrors do creep,</br>Like frost, thro' the wanderer's breast—</br>When flow'rets in sorrow do weep,</br>And all nature in mourning is drest;
O then before heaven I'll kneel—</br>"May God my Fidelia defend—</br>May the pangs and the torture I feel,</br>Ne'er wreath the dear heart of my friend."</br>
